item.description:
The board is made up of 7 circles arranged in a hexagonal grid making up a large hexagon. Every other circle on the outer ring is coloured red. Although the board can be made up of Hexagons instead.

The white player must get 1 stack of six. The stack can be made up of black pieces as well as white pieces, or can be made up of just one colour. Even if the black player makes the stack, it still counts.

If white immobilizes black, then white wins. Black must immobilize white.

An entry into the About.com: 2002 Unequal Forces Game Design Competition.

600 questions about movies, music, & more plus a special die in a small, wedge-shaped storage container.

The game does not feature a game board, and thus, there is no roll-and-move mechanic. Instead, players roll the color-coded die, and answers a question matching the color rolled. If a player correctly answers a question, he may "go for a wedge" by answering another question in the same category. If he does so, he keeps that card. If the player answers a question incorrectly, it is the next player's turn. Play ends when a player has collected six cards/correctly answered 12 questions.
600 questions about things you do while you're just kickin' back in a wedge-shaped storage container.
600 questions about music and the people who make it (and more) in a wedge-shaped storage container.
600 questions about sports, computer games, and board games in a wedge-shaped storage container.

Get into your car, catch the runaway criminals and be the first to return to the Motorway Police District.

This is the official game of the 1996 German TV serial "Alarm für Cobra 11 - Die Autobahnpolizei" (Alarm for Cobra 11 - The Motorway Police).

Contents of the box:
- 30 Wanted cards
- 19 Joker cards
- 6 reward cards
- 1 cardboard map
- 6 stand up cars
- 1 rulebook
- 3 dice

A childrens' card game. The object is to be the first to get rid of all your cards.

The dealer shuffles the pack and deals the required number of cards to each player. He spreads out the "spare" cards, face up, in the centre of the table. On their turn a player turns up his top card and tries to place it on any of the "spare" cards in ascending or descending order. If he can't follow the sequence they place the card face up next to his own pile. Other players who can't play a card on the "spare" cards can instead play a card in seqence onto any of the other player's face-up cards. If they can't, they put the card in their own face-up pile.

If a player places a card incorrectly the other players shout "Folly" and they each give you a card from their face-down piles to add to your pile. When your face-down pile runs out, turn your face-up pile face-down and carry on. The first player to get rid of all his cards wins.

name.value: Mr Uppity's Game of Beggar My Neighbour

item.description: Each player starts with a face-down deck of cards. In turn each player places their top card in the middle of the table. When a "Put" card is played, the next player has to put down the number of cards required. If they play a "Put" card, then their turn ends and the next player goes. If no "Put" card turns up in the cards put down, the player who laid the last "Put" card gets all the cards from the centre of the table. A player who runs out of cards is out of the game. The last player left in the game is the winner.

name.value: Europa: Paris ist ja klar, aber wo liegt Córdoba?
Europa: Venedig ist ja klar, aber wo liegt Nessebar?

item.description:
Europa is the next game in line from KOSMOS' geography series (previous installments: Deutschland - Finden Sie Minden! and Globalissimo).

The game expands the idea from 'Deutschland' to a European map, where the players have to locate cities, rivers/lakes, landscapes/regions and historical sites. In doing so, the players can decide how much risk they take by choosing how detailed they get in their localization attempt.
The systems works more or less like betting at roulette; the smaller the region you guessed, the higher the return. But if you make a mistake you get nothing at all! 
Europa is to 'Deutschland' what 'Ausgerechnet, Uppsala!' was to 'Ausgerechnet, Buxtehude!'. It just takes the game to another geographical level. 
The only major difference is the catch-up mechanism: Instead of allowing trailing players to jump over occupied fields on the point track, the game reuses the 'barriers' from 'Globalissimo'. The leading player has to guess the country of a certain location in order to advance further on the point track. Trailing players can then proceed without such a trial. Additionally, the last player may make a bonus guess by correcting or detailing another player's guess for a bonus point.

item.description:
At first you think you are playing good old Monopoly where they just add some extra buildings to give a little twist. But the longer you play, the more you realise they actually made a whole new game. You start with more money than usual, which gives you the idea you will last longer (with a bit of luck maybe). The fact that now you can build right away when you bought a property, gives so much dynamic to the game. No more waiting until you have the whole set, or not having the set because one player refuses to trade. Even with a couple of single properties you can win the game.

But not so fast. Everybody wants to win of course. And with the 80 extra buildings they added to the game, nothing was ever so uncertain. On every property you can build residential or industrial buildings. The first is not protected against negative buildings (hazards) and requires positive buildings otherwise the property becomes worthless. The industrial buildings on the other hand are protected but they cost twice as much! So you will have to make choice. And the added electronic device will, besides timing deals, always indicate how many buildings you can exactly make.

There is also no community chest anymore, only chance. But they have changed the content of the cards which makes the game less predictable and more fun to play- watch your buildings being crushed because of an earthquake or not getting your rent because a player evades the number thrown with the dice.

Besides these changes, there are many more twists to the game which I will not reveal here but be sure that they all add to the greatness that once was and that now has even become better.

Monopoly City made its first public appearance at the Nuremberg Toy Fair 2009.

item.description:
On the heels of the very successful Battlestations Adventure Game, comes a new stand alone game in the Battlestations Universe. Instead of controlling one crew member in adventure style missions you’ll be able to play Battlestations: Fleet Actions taking charge of multiple ships and crews. No referee is needed as players battle each other for mission objectives, all the while gaining prestige, leveling up their crews with new ship wide special abilities.

Featured is a new sleek rule set that has all the familiar Battlestations feel, but built for quicker and faster resolution on a massive scale. The familiar power levels in the ships are there with a few minor tweaks. For starters, all ships have unlimited helm power allowing them to perform a number of actions a phase only limited by the number of pilots. As a drawback however, any ship that fails in a piloting maneuver loses the rest of it’s actions! Make sure those pilots go last! If you have to turn the ship to fire weapons make sure you make your skill check! Guns and shields work a little differently. The size of your ship determines the power that both guns and shields can have combined. It’s up to the player to decide how that power is split. So a size 9 ship has 9 points of power to split between guns and shields. Unlike Battlestations energy levels never drop and there’s no more power generation before a round begins. This means there’s only ever two times during the course of the game that you have to adjust power levels; if your engines go down or if you transfer power. No more power booking keeping between rounds.

Another new game mechanic is automatic actions. By activating crew some actions happen automatically.

name.value: Animal Upon Animal: The Card Game

item.description: Card Game version of Haba's Award-winning Animal Upon Animal Game. Players stack cards on top of a wooden crocodile.

To the track, get set and go! The course leads from red to blue, from yellow to green. Who will take the lead and snatch the right car in the end?

A breathtaking card game for 2-4 players. Includes variation for expert racers.

- Card game with wooden game material

item.description:
Wow, the Geometry Pirates have discovered the hexagonal island where the notorious pirate Geometrikus has buried his treasure: golden spheres, glittering pyramids and much more. The pirates equipped with the square treasure card and the round compass go on the exciting treasure hunt. The game collection acquaints 1-4 pirates with geometric shapes and solids and trains spatial perception.

Includes guide to geometry.

Game comes with a cloth game board, wooden squares and instructions in a heavy drawstring bag. Instructions say that the game is a game of logic and strategy for 2 to 4 people. The game is published by Scuda games of Boston.

"A fun and exciting card game for kids and adults. Over 100 cards that will keep memories of the 20th Century alive forever."

This unique deck has one card for each year from 1900 to 1998, with 5 events that happened that year, of all types: politics, sports, arts, inventions, etc. There are also two 1999 cards, which act like wild cards, and four 2000 "Millenium Bug" cards, that are penalty cards. The events each have an icon next to them to show a specific type: e.g. car, tennis player, Olympic rings, airplane, dollar sign, national flag, anchor, skull, etc.

There are rules to three games included. In all of them, 10 cards are dealt to each player.

Century Classic is rummy-like: during their turn players draw, lay down melds, and discard. Acceptable melds are: chains, 3 or more consecutive years; and matches: 3 or more that have the same event icon. Players can also add to their previous melds, but not to others'. When a player goes out, the others receive penalty points for what's left in their hand. 1999 cards are wild, and each player may use their birth year as a personal wild. If you have a 2000 card may play it to the table and draw a replacement, taking up your whole turn; 2000's in your hand at the end add to your penalties.

Century Chain is Uno-like. Players may play a card to the discard pile if it matches one of its icons, or is adjacent in year. You may continue playing until you have nothing left. If you have nothing to start, you may draw one card instead. (1999s and 2000s are not included in this game.) First player out of cards wins.

Century Face Off is a quasi-trick-taking game. Players take turns playing a card to the center, and the one who played highest year takes the trick and leads to the next. After the 10 cards are out, another 10 each (or however many are left) are dealt out. Winner is the one who takes the most tricks.

This game has 32 cards, each one representing a wild animal, with its name, a photograph, its habitat on a world map, and its value in 5 attributes: Size, Max Speed, Weight, Lifespan, and Danger Lever (the latter from 1 to 10). There is also a card that just says "Flax". And, two rules cards, and a title card that advertises the other versions: Flax Dinosaurs, and Flax Creatures of the Sea.

The Flax basic game is War-like. All the cards are dealt out, and everyone looks at their top card. The leading player picks one attribute and reads it out loud ("Okapi, Max Speed 35 mph".) Everyone lays their card down and the card with the highest value in that attribute takes the lot; they go to the bottom of the winner's pile and he leads to the next trick. The "Flax" card wins any trick but only may be used once. The ultimate winner is the one who gets all the cards.

In the advanced game, players may look at their whole hand. The leader chooses a card and a category, and only players who can beat it play to the middle. The one who takes the trick leads next; but the game is won by the player who gets rid of all their cards first.

item.description:
Trafalgar Naval Warfare in the Age of Sail (1795-1815) by Warhammer Historical Wargames Ltd is a set of tabletop wargame rules set during the time of the Napoleonic Wars. Fleetlists are supplied for all the major and several minor powers of Europe as well as the American Navy. The book also includes a brief historical review and a hobby section.

From the website...

It was a battle that captured the hearts of a nation, and changed the balance of naval power for a hundred years to come. It was a battle that made men into heroes, and turned a hero into a legend.

Warhammer Historical is proud to present Trafalgar, a naval wargame, set in the Age of Sail. Within this book you will find all the rules, history and hobby information you need to fight battles between opposing navies throughout the period 1795-1815. From the Battle of Copenhagen and the Glorious 1st June, the war in the Baltic, and the eponymous Battle of Trafalgar itself, to the naval War of 1812 between Britain and the emerging naval superpower of the United States, all are contained within this volume.

Whether you’re inspired by the history and romance of massive, bloody battles on the high seas, or wish to recreate the fictional exploits of Hornblower and Aubrey, Trafalgar provides an accessible set of rules and practical information to bring these encounters to life through a strategic tabletop wargame.

Set sail for adventure and glory. Clear for action, beat to quarters, and run out the guns: Every man must do his duty!

item.description:
Six cards are on the table. Players place bets on any of those (no tokens included for some reason) and roll three dice. The dice show on of the cards on each of their sides. If the cards you bet on are rolled, you get double your money back (one die), triple (two dice) or quadruple (all three dice). No goal is set, players just play as long as they want.
Was one of six little games in Piatnik's Texas Series in 1989.

Dice rolling game from the 1989 "Texas Series" published by Piatnik. Cards are placed on the table and form the "game board" Players move by combining the results of three dice in any way they see fit. In this way, they have to reach the exact number displayed on the next card of the route. You have to move to the 12th card and back in order to win the game.

name.value: Turning Point: Fleet Action 2 Master Rules

item.description:
From the back of the book:

"It seemed like only a few hours since the ENS Horan had backed out of the docking arm at Saturn Base. In truth, it has been several days, each intervening day filled with frantic activity as the crew prepared for the forthcoming battle. Now that battle was upon them. On the plot, two fleets could be seen closing in on one another. As the captain of the Horan watched, flanking forces detached themselves first from the European fleet, quickly followed by matching elements from the Union fleet. These elements would attempt to get around the heavy screens to the key units the escorts were protecting, the flagship and carriers. Soon the battle would truly be joined...
__________________________________________________________
What you hold in your hands is the Master Rules to the Fleet Action 2 combat system as well as the introductory information to the epic Turning Point Universe. These rules will allow you to fight massive battles involving potentially dozens of ships and even more fighters. If that's not enough, a highly robust and flexible design system will allow you to create the fleet of your dreams, whether it be from your favourite sci-fi epic or concocted from the deepest realms of your imagination.

Highlights of the Fleet Action 2 combat system...

 Modular design allows for easier expansion
 Combined arms mechanics encouraging the use of speciality ships such as escorts and carriers
 A myriad of types of weapons, each with their own strengths & weaknesses
 Streamlines combat rules allowing for large numbers of warships
 Simple but flexible fighter rules make large numbers of fighters simple to wield
 Powerful and robust custom design rules allow for the design of new weapons, ships, ammunition types and fighters"




Notes: This was published as a loose-leaf rulebook, pre-drilled for 4-ring binders. Originally intended to update Fleet Action in the Babylon 5 universe, Agents of Gaming lost the franchise during development, and so developed a setting of near-space settlement with various Earth nations and coalitions as the factions. An extensive line of miniatures was planned , but only the first few released before AoG ceased trading and closed it's doors for the final time.

A light-hearted game of insecticide and stress for three to five players.

In the battle against vermin, you're either with Sherbie, or against her. Amass an army of silverfish and send them to torment Sherbie, or grab a paper towel and some bug spray and attempt to defeat the insectile menace. In the end, only one side can triumph.

Object: Be the player with the most silverfish in either your Sherbie stress pile or your squish pile.

Equipment: Each player needs a pencil and a sheet of paper marked as follows:


 Two 10x10 grids of squares, each grid should have rows labeled with A at the top through J at the bottom. Columns should be labeled with 1 at the left to 10 at the right. These grids will be referred to as your secret grid (the maze your opponent is trying to navigate) and your open grid (where you are trying to navigate the maze made by your opponent). You should not show your paper to your opponent at any time in the game.
 Space to write down your robot's program each turn.
 Space to mark your robot's health.


Robot Maze Race is a maze-solving game. Each player tries to program their robot to maneuver through a disorganized warehouse without bumping into too may crates or walls on the way.

An entry into the About.com: 2005 Deduction Game Design Competition.

This is a twist on the classic game Othello/Reversi. The player playing the black pieces (that is the black side of the pieces) is called Black. The other player plays the white pieces and is called White. In Reviser the players play different roles. One player will play the 'Setter,' the other will play the 'Jumper.' Setter and Jumper keep their role during the whole game. At his turn, the Setter places one of his pieces on the board. That piece must be in line with one of his pieces so that one or more opponents pieces are between them (without any empty fields between them). These opponents pieces are flipped. This is the same mechanism as in Reversi. At his turn the Jumper must jump with one of his pieces (on the board) over any number of his opponents pieces in a straight line. The opponents pieces he jumped over are flipped. He may continue to jump with that piece if possible. He must not jump over his own pieces or over empty fields.

The game ends if one player is unable to make a legal move. The player with the greater number of his pieces on the board wins the game.

An entry into the About.com: 2002 Unequal Forces Game Design Competition.

Equipment:

* A standard chess set and board
 * 4 pieces that represent the Yin and Yang contained in both teams: one clear stone, one translucent black stone, one opaque white stone, and one opaque black stone

Praxis is a chess variant that incorporates the Zen philosophy of opposing forces defining the Way. Ancient books, such as the I Ching, show the interaction of these two forces, Yin and Yang, and their effect upon human life. Praxis is an attempt to bring these forces into a game that already presents the struggle between opposing forces.

From the game's designer:

'This is a Chess variant I created in college. I uncovered it in a recent basement purge. I scanned it and posted the scans then destroyed the original due to mildew damage. Once you get over the early 90's graphics... it might just be playable!'

Available from http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

Por'rika(c) (Sacred Waters) is an old Schelati(c) game. The Schelati are a species of amphibians that have, since the beginning of recorded history, laid their eggs in the Sacred Waters. These Sacred Waters, however, happened to be located in the prime hunting territory for the Ser'ra(c), large birds of prey that were the Schelati's only natural enemy. The game is based on this conflict.

The object of the copper side is to get both Egg-Carriers into the Scared Water spaces. The object of the silver side is to stop that from happening.

An entry into the About.com: 2002 Unequal Forces Game Design Competition.

Summary: Place 25 cards sequentially in a 5-by-5 grid with an object to score the highest Poker combinations in each row and column.

Equipment: 

 a shuffled standard (French) 52-card deck
 a pen and Poker Squares grid for each player




Rules: Each turn, a card is drawn from the deck and announced. Each player must then privately write the card rank and suit (e.g. “10C” for 10 of Clubs, “AH” for Ace of Hearts) in any empty cell of their 5-by-5 grid. Once written in the grid, cards may not be moved. After all players have written the card, the next turn begins. When player grids are full after 25 cards, grids are scored.
 
Scoring: The 5-card hand of each grid row and column is scored according to a point system.





 Poker Squares Hand Scoring Systems

 
 Poker Hand 
 American Points 
 English Points

 
 
 Royal Flush 
 100 
 30

 
 
 Straight Flush 
 75 
 30

 
 
 Four of a Kind 
 50 
 16

 
 
 Full House 
 25 
 10

 
 
 Flush 
 20 
 5

 
 
 Straight 
 15 
 12

 
 
 Three of a Kind 
 10 
 6

 
 
 Two Pair 
 5 
 2

 
 
 One Pair 
 2 
 1

 
 
 High Card 
 0 
 0

 


A player's total score is the sum of the hand scores for each of the 10 row and column hands.

Pipelayer is a game played with two grids of dots that are slightly offset from one another. The long dimension should be one longer than the short dimension.

The players take turns moving by connecting two dots. A player can only connect dots that are adjacent horizontally or vertically and also only dots of his own color. No move may draw across another move. To win a player must make a continuous connection from one side of the board to the other in the long direction for his color of dots.

An animated example is available on the game's website.

Equipment: Package War! requires a minimum of 16 six-sided dice, and pencil and paper for noting points scored. 26 six-sided dice are recommended.

Package War! is a two player game where each player takes on the role of a package shipping mogul determined to dominate the industry and crush the competition. In this cut-throat game, each shipping magnate tries to foil the competition by crushing their packages and stacking their own packages as high as they can. Be the first to dominate the package shipping industry!

An entry into the About.com: 2004 Shared Pieces Game Design Competition.

Answer science questions and move around the board in the hunt for the questions that give you points. Guess the year of an event and the closer to the year you get, the more points you earn.
The playing pieces are famous scientists like Einstein and Pasteur.
Like in Trivial Pursuit knowledge is the most important factor in deciding the winner.

Reality Show is an nontraditional 'soft' psychological party game. The players carry out lot of activities. The basic system of the game can be divided in two parts: covering frame and the game tasks.

Covering frame: is inspired by TV reality shows. Players represent imaginary persons who are part of an imaginary TV reality show. Their lives are filmed by cameras... In this frame players develop their identities while entering into the world of plots, strategies and psychology. After a certain time some players fall out (he/she can't try to gain the main award) and he/she continues as a 'passive' player (who is supposed to be noticeably active).

Tasks of play: is a collection of cards with more than 60 tasks and the center of the game. Most tasks have a certain psychological background. But this psychological element is rather only an additional dimension of tasks and it isn't necessary for players to mark it. Players draw one task card in each round, they read a setting and a certain numbers of players will be able to register to the task. If the task is carried out he/she will get a number of votes (this number of supposed votes is chosen by each player himself/herself before carrying out the task). Players can carry out about 16 tasks in each game.

This is a childrens game. Put the tower together, choose your color on your players. Roll the dice and put one of your player on the same color level the dice showing. If the tower falls you have lost this game.

Contents:
24 color figures
1 dice
1 tower

All people that like Siri and Sigge Spratt (Buster & Babs Bunny) have hidden at the Looniversitetet (ACME Looniversity) and your job is to find them. Your friends are on 20 tiles and the person who find the most friends of the same color wins this game. But be aware: Siris and Sigges enemies have also hid and will give you some trouble if you find them instead.

item.description: This is a piecepack port. Fan Tan is believed to have been invented by Kwan Chung, a renowned statesmen of antiquity who died in 645BC. There is a likelihood that the game was invented for soldiers as a way for them to pass the time in camp. The name means spreading out, as the real life version involves spreading out coins or buttons in groups of four until there is a remainder of none to three. San Francisco's large chinese community had dozens of Fan Tan Houses in the 19th century. Fan tan is still played at Macau casinos, where play goes on day and night, every day of the week, and bets can be made from 5 cents to 500 dollars.

Three Inspectors have come to Chicago, and your gang wants to make sure they don't get any information about the family. The same thought has occurred to your nemesis, and you've both gathered your family and those loyal to you, ready for a fight.

Flickago is a flicking game where each player is trying to keep their gang members in the other gang's turf in order to keep the inspectors -out- of their home turf.

There's more strategy than just flicking hard, and plenty of decisions.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: A light multi-player wargame of sci-fi fantasy combat. Strategic, tactical, and dice intensive. Players have a set army on their home planets that they recruit with their starting units, forming groups. These groups move around on the board, and when they meet another group, they combat. Combat is done via dice rolls, (Lots of them!), but each character has his own number of dice and special power to consider.

This is a gin-rummy-type word card game, whose object is to be the first to clear your hand.

The deck has 54 cards, two of each letter and two wild cards. Players are dealt 9 cards each for 2, 3 or 4 players, 8 each for 5, and 7 each for 6. In a turn, a player draws one card from the draw or discard pile, lays down a word or adds to an existing word, and discards one.

The first player to go out gets one point per card in everyone else's hands; if the draw pile runs out the hand ends and the player with fewest cards wins the points. The game is won at 25 points. If a players spells "zest" without wild cards, he gets 25 points and wins immediately.

In this dice rolling game, players try to make a connection of three, four and five. The roll of the die determines what character should be filled in on the scoring form: X,0 or -. You can only win this game with a little luck of the die and a lot of strategic thinking.

This word card game has the uncommon feature that each card has two letters on it -- either one can be used to make a word. (They are in opposite corners, but in each corner you see one letter, its value, and the letter in the opposite corner.) Of the 105 cards, 8 of them have a are wild cards in one corner, and four are wild on both ends.

Each player is dealt 8 cards, and the top card of the draw pile is used to start the discard pile. In a turn, a player makes a word starting with either letter of the top discard, and using cards from his hand for the rest. The letters' values -- ranging from 2 to 20 -- are added for the word's score, which is added to the player's total. The word is then discarded, the player fills out their hand back to 8 from the draw pile, and the next player takes a turn, using the new top discard to start a word.

Players pass if they cannot make a word from their hand. The game ends when every player passes in turn, typically after the draw pile is exhausted. The lower value of each card in hand is subtracted from the players' scores, and the highest total wins. Optional rules allow bonus points for long words.

A Skin-crawling card game for 3-6 players.

You have an infestation problem and the only way to deal with it is to give it to someone else!

In Roaches! all players begin with a hand of cards representing their roach infestation. By forming pairs they may discard these cards either to other players or to a central pile on the table. By playing your cards on an opponent you can keep them from returning the favour, but by playing to the pile you can draw a special event card which may have the power to change the game ... because at any time you might just get stuck with every roach on the table!

This game is free for download at http://kenmgames.wordpress.com

This word card game has 108 cards, most with a letter and value (1-9), except for two wild cards with value zero.

Each player is dealt 10 cards. In their turn, a player may: form a new word from their hand; add from their hand to either end of a word already on the table; discard any number of their cards to the bottom of the draw pile; or pass. If they played or added to a word, they score all points in the word, then draw back up to 10. If a wild card is on the table, and they have a card for the letter it stands for, they may swap it for the wild card, at the start of their turn.

Play ends when the draw pile is exhausted and one player exhausts his hand or everyone passes in turn. The values of the cards in hand are subtracted from the scores, and the highest wins.

Fancy yourself as a trivia king or queen? Find out who the brainiest bar-flies are as you enjoy a traditional pub quiz - in the comfort of your home.

If you're a quiz whiz then this is the game for you. Great general knowledge and quick thinking are what counts here, and if you and your fellow players want to be crowned pub champs, then team work is a must! Be ready to notch up points in the quick fire rounds then blast the opposition in 2 blistering bonus heats. So get your thinking caps on - and the drinks in!

name.value: Roll Dice Kill Monsters Have Fun Dungeon Crawler

item.description: ROLL DICE KILL MONSTERS HAVE FUN DUNGEON CRAWLER is a fresh take on mazes, this game is more than just finding a path from start to finish, it's also about overcoming the obstacles along the way. The obstacles come in the form of traps and adversaries. The traps are whatever the players imagine them to be they could be a pit of spikes, a falling boulder, etc. The adversaries are met by the players by means of a random encounter system, defeating adversaries will most certainly garner usable rewards for the players. In ROLL DICE KILL MONSTERS HAVE FUN DUNGEON CRAWLER there are two kinds of mazes. The first is to successfully reach the finish from a set start point. The second is to successfully meet and defeat a boss type character. ROLL DICE KILL MONSTERS HAVE FUN DUNGEON CRAWLER is the groundbreaking amalgamation of a board game and an analog role playing game, without any of the convoluted aspects of analog role playing games.

A tactical science fiction ship combat game played on a hex map. Fleets are created by allocating build points and designing ships. Different races have unique weapons and other characteristics.

The entire game comes in a 3" x 5" ziplock bag. The rule book is 2.5" x 3.5" and has 30 pages. A folded hex map (8" x 9") with tiny 1/4" hexes is included and has ship templates for all 6 races on the opposite side. Includes two d6 dice, each 0.50cm on a side.

Originally costing $1, this may be the smallest wargame ever produced!

This is a re-make of Mamma Mia! that incorporates cards from Sole Mio!, includes enough cards for a sixth player, and adds a new ingredient (shrimp).

Each player is given fifteen different pizza orders to fill, and on his turn adds ingredient cards and then an optional pizza order to a common pile. After the draw pile is exhausted, the common pile is flipped over and the cards in it are sorted by ingredient until an order comes up. If there are enough ingredient cards to fill the order, the player scores it. If there aren't enough, the player can either make up the difference with cards from his hand or put the order back into his 'to be filled' pile. After three to four rounds, the player with the most filled orders wins.

Contents:

 90 Ingredient cards (15 each of Pineapple, Olive, Green Pepper, Mushroom, Salami, Shrimp)
 90 Order cards (15 orders in each of 6 player colors)
 Rules in German, English, French, and Italian

name.value: Starpower: Tactical Ship Combat in the 29th Century

item.description:
Subtitled: Tactical Ship Combat in the 29th Century, Starpower is the first game in the "Four Empires Series". It is a tactical science fiction miniatures game played on a large surface. It uses pre-written orders for each turn. There are minimal special abilities for the four "empires".

The game ships in a ziplock bag including a 32-page rulebook with advanced and optional rules, information on the four empires, and fleet compositions. Also included are reproducible ship miniatures and status sheets, an order sheet, a boarding template, tables, and counters for boarding parties and small craft.

Fast and Dirty was designed to provide a quick, uncomplicated, yet realistic game system for small unit modern day, near future and sci-fi skirmish combat.

By building upon basic military principles that have not changed much over time, such as troop morale, motivation, and experience, these rules are an attempt to create a system that will serve just as well for fire fights today as those far off into the future.

Each player will field a small force, ranging from a few squads to a reinforced platoon with support elements, including heavy weapons, artillery, even a vehicle or two. Forces can be created in one of three ways: using a simple random force generation system to get you playing quickly, a more advanced system for experienced players, and a detailed points system for the ultimate in flexibility. Though the system is easy to learn and play, this doesn’t mean the game is lacking details.

In fact, there are actually three levels of play. First you will learn the Basic Game, which provides all the core rules necessary to head off into battle. Then, as you become familiar with the system, you might want to consider using some of the Advanced Rules, which will add more depth to your gaming experience. Finally, there are a number of Optional Rules which you can incorporate into your games to add even greater detail. The choice is yours.

Fast and Dirty is a generic system, specifically designed to work with a wide array of settings and miniatures. Feel free to devise your own worlds and forces, based upon the miniatures in your collection.

item.description: A dice rolling game for smaller children. The players lay out cards (face down) and roll dice to move Snowwhite, a prince and a witch along the card path. A card on which a movement ends is turned face up. Witch or Snowwhite/prince can win by reaching the dwarves' house first, but only if they have picked up certain cards along the way.

From the publisher's website:

Guns Blazing is the 2nd game in the Down In Flames series. This stand-alone game adds 55 more types of aircraft, new campaigns, and action cards featuring the new aircraft!

Down In Flames places each player in the cockpit of a Leader and Wingman as they enter combat against other aircraft. By playing cards, you gain advantageous positions on your targets, fire your guns, and send them down in flames!

The game is based on a unique action-reaction card mechanic. Each card can be countered by specific other cards. At the bottom of every card is the list of cards it is allowed to cancel. This makes for exciting card play back and forth between players...

Player #1: "I Play an In My Sights for 3 Hits. If you don’t stop it, you’re going down." Player #2: "I counter with a Barrel Roll." Player #1: "I react with a Yo-Yo." Player #2: "You got me."

Each aircraft is accurately simulated with several ratings including: Performance (the maximum cards you can hold), Horsepower (the maximum cards you can draw each turn), Bursts (how many times you can fire), Damage (how much damage your attacks inflict), and Airframe (how much damage your aircraft can sustain).

The air combat is simulated using a Positioning system that allows aircraft to be Advantaged, Tailing, Disadvantaged, or Tailed in relation to other aircraft. An aircraft’s position determines if it can attack, and how many bonus Bursts it receives if it is Advantaged or Tailing.

The game uses a simple Altitude system to add this vital aspect of air combat. Aircraft get to draw cards when diving, and must discard cards when climbing.

The game also includes Light, Medium, and Heavy Bombers that are used in the historical campaign games.

Components
110 Full color Action Cards
110 Full Color Aircraft Cards
Full Color 24 Page Rulebook
Full Color Counter Sheet (176 - 5/8” counters)
6 Full Color Campaigns
Full Color Player Log Sheet

Scheduled Aircraft Cards: 
GERMANY
Bf-110G2, Fw-190A6, He-177, Ju-87D, Me-163, Do-335, He-162, Henchel, Bf-109G10, Bf-109F2

JAPAN
G8N Rita, N1K2 George, J7W1, Ki84 Frank, Sally, A6M8 Zeke, A6M6 Zeke

UK
Buffalo, Spitfire IX, Lancaster, Meteor, Tempest, Halifax, Typhoon, Beaufighter

USA
P-38F, P-47B, B-25, B-17G, Avenger, B-29, B-24J, F4U-4

SOVIET
I-15, I-153, I-16-29, LaGG-3, La-5, Yak-3

FRENCH
M.S. 406, D.520, Potez 630, MB-152, Amiot 143, LeO.451, Farman F.222

ITALIAN
C.R. 42 Falco, M.C. 200 Saetta, M.C. 202 Folgore, M.C. 205 Veltro, G.50 Freccia, Re-2001, Re-2005, Breda Ba.88, Savoia-Marchetti SM.79, Savoia-Marchetti SM.81, Breda Ba.65, Piaggio P.108

Scheduled Campaigns
Italian
French
Daylight 1945
Pacific 1944
Soviet
North Africa

The aircraft and campaign list is still a work in progress. In the end, there will be 55 different types of aircraft totaling 110 cards, and 6 campaigns.

link.value: Down in Flames: Guns Blazing – Extra Decks

item.description: A game based on the game Guillotine, where players get cards with actions and persons somehow connected to the Bank Crisis in Iceland, whether they be politicians, business-men, tv personalities and so on. Players play their cards (one person and one action card each round) and try to get the 25 points needed to win.

A game based on the tv show 70 mínútur (70 minutes). Players move along the 70 spaces on the track and have to answer questions, do silly things (called challenges) or drink the Disgusting Drink (the ingredients being various substances blended as the game progresses).

Fast Action Hockey (DMC Games) is an exciting statistical simulation board game that lets you replay the NHL championships--or the entire 2000-2001 season--solitaire, or in head-to-head competition with a friend. Over 650 individually rated players representing all 30 teams are yours to command.

Fast Action Hockey plays quickly because it focuses on the "fun stuff"--shooting and scoring--while eliminating time-consuming elements that add little or nothing to the excitement such as face-offs, puck passing, penalties, line changes, time-clock tracking, etc. What makes FAH even better is the ease and quickness of play. You won’t have to spend an hour or two playing a single game. Instead, once you are familiar with the play sequence and the charts, you can play a game in 20 minutes or less, and easily replay the entire Stanley Cup finals in one evening!

Basic Sequence of Play

There are three phases to FAH:

1) Select 18 players and 1 goaltender from each team and list them on the score sheet.

2) Determine the number of shots each player will take during the game and write down in the "SOG" column of the scoresheet. To do this, check for the player’s shots grade ("Sh" on the roster sheet), roll all 3 dice and consult the "Player Shots" chart.

3) Resolve the shots for each player (i.e., determine the outcome of each player’s shots on goal.) and assign assists (the number of assists for each goal is indicated on the goal scoring chart).

Fast Action Hockey will produce lifelike statistical performances over the course of an entire replay season when playing schedules similar to the actual.

(Game was marketed on a limited scale in 2001 only, and sold primarily through Ebay).

Mia is an ancient bluffing dice game using two dice and a cup to conceal the dice. It is believed to have been played by the Vikings. There are affinities with Liar's Dice (and the card game Bullshit), but also some interesting differences.

Players take turns rolling the dice beneath a cup and announcing a higher roll than the previous roll. This announcement can be challenged, with the roller losing a life if caught lying, and the challenger losing a life if the roller was truthful (players typically start with three lives). There is also the option (instead of rolling the dice oneself or challenging the previous roller) of passing your turn (without viewing the roll under the cup) to the next player. In this case the passer assumes responsibility for the roll as if he or she had rolled it him- or herself. (Thus, if the next player challenges the announced value, it is the passer who stands to lose a life if the value under the cup is not that which was announced.)

One interesting feature of Mia is the non-standard ordering of rolls. "21" is "Mia", the highest roll. Next come the doubles in ascending order: 11 is the second best roll, then 22, 33, 44, 55, 66. From there the numbers descend, with the higher die always naming the tens value and the lower die naming the ones value: 65, 64, 63, 62, 61, 54, 53, 52, 51, 43, 42, 41, 32, and 31 as the lowest value.

Similar to Cheat.

item.description:
A new "Ice Age" has struck the planet! 
Ice floes are circling the oceans, allowing Antarctic penguins to drift into the territory of Arctic polar bears. 
Get your penguins safely from the South Pole to the North Pole across drifting ice floes whilst watching out for a hungry Polar Bear. 
This is a piecepack port of Milton-Bradley’s "Polar Dare!"

In this game waits the most delicious cream cake on you and your opponents. And the best part is that you can take as many pieces of the cake that you wants without having stomach problems. In your hand you can carry cards of strawberries , candy and many more ingredients. The person who have taken the most pieces of the cake will win this game.

Contents:
1 boardgame
1 cream cake (16 pieces and a marzipanrose in the middle)
48 candy cards
1 dice
1 recipe
Rules inside of the front box.

You are composers, haunted by music that you didn't write, and also doesn't exist. As such, all of you are in an asylum. To regain your sanity, you have to complete three of the compositions haunting you. Unfortunately, there are only so much paper and ink available at a time. Also, the asylum tries to keep as many of its patients in group therapy at a time as it can.

Players invest their tempo(represented by metronomes) to obtain the materials, time, and inspiration needed to complete the pieces haunting them. There are currently two card decks, one for 3-4 players and one for 5-6.

In the Sunes room there is the entry to the closet. While you're in there you will play a Russian postman who gives away dare, hugs or kisses, but you wont know to whom your giving it to.

Contents:
1 boardgame
10 tiles with persons on it
100 cards
5 playing pieces
1 dice
1 rule sheet

Do you dare to enter this monster castle? In the castle some terrible monsters will wait for you such as Greve Cranium, Ms bat, Frankenstein, Kryptonia and many more. The house is full with bats, spiders, craniums and chests. Can you lay the puzzle and find the creature in the castle before anyone else? Then you will escape with your life and the other are doomed for the eternity.

Contents:
The box as a boardgame
1 bat
1 spider
1 chest with 20 puzzle pieces
1 cranium
1 book storytelling of Greve Cranium 
34 cards
2 dice

The game with a lot of challenges. You have to prove your self worthy in 15 different challenges to get around the board. Do you have what it takes to get to the finish line?
Do you feel just lucky or are you a master of tactics in the challenges?

Will you master basket, skating, golf, throwing rings, number games, spelling games, higher or lower, quiz just to mention some of the challenges.

Scene It? - Doctor Who takes the mechanic of the base Scene It? Movie game and specializes to Doctor Who TV series trivia.

As in previous versions of Scene It? Movie games, the players select pawns and move along a board answering trivia questions. There are three categories of questions on the question cards, and there are many categories of questions on the DVD which includes clips from the Doctor Who TV series.

This game features only the Doctor Who TV series starring David Tennant.

The mummy King Ramses wants to conquer Egypt using his mummies. To stop him, be the first to collect the most magical crystals, evade the mummies and climb the pyramid.

"The board and dice are built in the traditional LEGO way with the game concept constructed and enacted as an extension of the LEGO build experience. Each game can be redesigned and reconstructed, offering endless play possibilities. Games can be adapted, using LEGO elements to enhance and ultimately evolve the game play."

item.description: Players try to remove groups of cards, but they can only remove a group of cards if the total adds up to 14, and if they are in the same row or the same column.

name.value: Korps Commander WWII: The Road to Berlin

item.description:
From the introduction to the rules:

Road to Berlin is a set of rules in the Korps Commander series, which will eventually cover all periods of warfare at a level which will allow large battles and campaigns to be fought. The series' aim is to utilize the techniques of boardgaming whilst retaining the flavour of miniature gaming.

Road to Berlin simulates actions in the Second World War on the Western or Eastern Fronts during the final two years for forces up to Corps or Army levels.

The basic units in the game are tank and mechanized infantry platoons, infantry companies, and artillery batteries. Aircraft may be in flights or squadrons, Logistics and engineers are fully covered.

A Corps level assault can easily be played on an 8' x 6' table, whilst the rules are ideal for campaign games where the action is spread across a number of tables.

This is a roll and move for 2-6 players, based on the amusement park in Branson, MO. There are two ways to play, Basic & Advanced. In the Basic game players travel around the park and the winner is the first person to land on the finish space by exact roll. In the Advanced game players travel around the board gathering as much money as possible. Once all players have traveled the board, the winner is the one with the most money.

A game contained in Spielbox #86 (Feb/Mar 2009)
Players must supply nine markers in each of two colors and a figure to use for the king.
(rough translation from description)
The Cabinet of Kings
A new king has come to power. He must recruit the best members of society for his cabinet. Who will get the most valuable seats in the cabinet.

This game is for two players who either place potential cabinet members on the board or move the king to recruit members. Some spots in the cabinet are worth more points than others, so players attempt to grab the best seats for their candidates, but cannot give up too many of the less valuable ones.

name.value: Around the House Treasure Hunt Game

item.description:
This game is a family game that puts a pirate themed spin on the cooperative treasure hunt. Players get one of several secret riddles printed up on scrolls. Once they solve the riddle and find the correct location, they then need to solve the next riddle they find there, and so on, until they find the hidden bag of treasure coins.

Game components:
-Game Box that looks just like a treasure chest
-Fabric Treasure Map
-Velour drawstring bag with nicely printed jolly roger
-Plastic Gold coins
-30 scrolls with riddles
-instructions.

This game's deck has 60 cards, in 5 colored suits: black is all vowels, while red, blue, yellow and green have one 'E' and the rest consonants. In most of the games, black is considered wild, belonging to any color. There four games described.

Al Pha Bet: All are dealt 7 cards. In a turn, a player draws 1 from the draw or discard pile, lays down a word or passes, and discards down to 7 if needed. Each word scores 5 per black vowel (there must be at least 1 per word), plus 1 per colored letter if there are at least 2 of them and they're all the same color; all doubled if the word is a palindrome (spelling another word backwards). Game ends after the draw pile's gone and all pass; highest total wins.

Alpha: Deal 7 face up to each player. In a turn, a player draws 1 and makes a word or passes and discards down to 7. If a word is played, each other player in turn gets a chance to add cards from their hand to the played word to make a different word, without changing the order. The last to add to the word wins it. Words score 1 per letter, doubled if monochrome, doubled if a palindrome.

Beta: A solitaire game. Deal 6 cards out in a line, starting 6 columns. You may move individual cards to the top of bottom of another column, removing words as completed. When done moving, deal another card to the bottom of each column (or empty slot if a column is empty). Continue until the deck is gone, trying to eliminate the whole deck.

Capa: A bridge-like partnership trick-taking game. Players first bid the number of words to make, along with a color (not black). Highest bid gets his color as trump, and his partner is dummy. Player to his left leads first. All plays must follow suit if possible, unless black is led. If a word is made in the color led, the leader wins the trick; if a word is made in a different color or multiple colors, the one who added the last card to it wins; if no word is made the leader wins. If the contractors get as many words as bid, they score for all words won, else the opponents score for all the words they won; words are scored as in Alpha.

WhizORD deck has 108 cards, each having a letter of the alphabet, and a value from 1-10, rarer letters being worth more. Rules for several games are included:

Poker-WhizORD: Like draw poker with 7 cards and one draw per hand. The player with the highest-scoring words adds it to his total. Alternate rules add chips and betting typical to poker, with up to 3 rounds of betting.

Soli-WhizORD: A solitaire game. Player deals himself 10 hands as if in Poker-WhizORD -- including one draw -- and scores their best word. The goal is 300 points.

Rummy-WhizORD: Players have 7-card hands, and in each turn they play and score a word or pass and discard any number of cards; then they draw back up to 7. Winner is the first to an agreed total.

Thirty-WhizORD: Players start with 7-card hands, and in their turn draw 1 and discard 1. The first player with a 30-point word in hand calls "Thirty!", lays it down and wins the hand. Play to an agreed number of hands or wins.

Hangman-WhizORD: Players each think of a word with the same number of letters, and pick their letters out of the deck, laying them out face down in the opponent's reading order. Take turns guessing letters, correct guesses being revealed, incorrect guesses being noted to avoid repeats. You may guess the word but if guessed wrong you lose; otherwise the first one to expose all the opponent's letters wins.

Match'Em-WhizORD: 12 or more matching pairs of letters are pulled from the deck, suffled and laid out on the table. Players reveal 2 cards in their turn, keeping matches, as in Concentration/Pelmanism.

Precitd-WhizORD: One card is revealed. Each player reveals another card in turn, but first predicts whether their card will precede or follow the first card. The player who predicted correctly, and has the letter closest to the first letter, captures all the cards; no one wins if a tie or a card matches the first one. At the end of the deck, the most cards captured wins.

From the box:

"We’ve made counting practice more fun than ever, with a super-involving game kids will love to play! Children just roll the die to move around the board collecting or giving away cute peanuts along the way. At the finish line, kids count up the peanuts in their bags and the player with the most peanuts wins the game! 2-4 players; with 4 rugged vinyl bags, plastic peanuts and more. Game board is 16" x 16".

From the box:

"Which of these silly ducks is hiding the secret egg? Just follow the quacking sound as the ducks spin ’round and ’round! But be sure to grab the right duck or you may end up with the rotten egg! Game includes all you need for up to 6 players; spinning nest measures 10".

From the Box:

"A real live game show you can host right in your own home! The Big Spin game lets contestants answer intriguing questions in 4 key categories: math, science, language and the arts. Kids just spin the wheel to select a category and earn points for each correct answer. The 14 1/2" write & wipe game board lets you tally up points as you play, and the game cards each have 3 different questions that vary in difficulty so kids of all abilities can play! With 80 game cards and a dry-erase marker. "

From the box:

"Kids piece these cool dinos together fact by fact! To play, kids answer fascinating questions about their favorite prehistoric reptiles, spin the spinner and collect plastic bones to build their own T-Rex or stegosaurus! You get 40 question cards, plus simple photo cards showing how to put the dinos together. T-Rex is 18 1/2".

From the box:

"Kids try to guess their opponent’s secret card and discover tons of cool creatures along the way from a Boa Constrictor and Bottlenose Dolphin to a Komodo Dragon! Played like 20 Questions, our game features 160 photo cards with fun facts on back like each animal’s size, diet, habitat and more. Kids just ask yes or no questions until they identify the other player’s animal and win the game! With two 11" game stadiums that hold the cards in place as children play."

From the box:

"With a super-strong leg that kicks the ball over 16 feet, this soccer star can score from anywhere on the field! Simply rotate his leg to angle the kick, then softly tap on his head to shoot short distances or whack him harder for extra-long shots. But watch out for the goalie as your opponent tries to block each shot and keep you from scoring! Comes complete with a scoreboard, 2 soft foam balls and 9 distance markers. Sturdy plastic goal is 15 1/2".

A word card game with a mild political theme. The deck has 52 letter cards, and 2 jokers which can stand for periods or apostrophes in contractions or abbreviations. (There is an elephant on the back of each card, and a donkey on the front of the jokers.) An extra deck is recommended if more than 3 play.

Players are dealt 10 cards, and the top of the draw is turned over to start the discard pile. In a turn a player draw one from either pile and discards one. If they think they have a winning hand they "call a vote", and everyone lays down their hands to score. The player with the highest-scoring hand adds its points, plus a 10-point bonus, to their total. Play to 150 points for the win.

One or more words can be formed from the hand when scoring, but the points favor longer words. Each word scores the "triangle number" of the number of letters it contains: 
1 - 1
2 - 3
3 - 6
4 - 10
5 - 15
6 - 21
7 - 28
8 - 36
9 - 45
10 - 55

There are several possible bonuses: a player who can use all his hand to spell words may "vote his hand" (similar to going Gin), automatically winning the hand and getting a 20-point bonus. Spelling certain Reward Words:
 WORK, THRIFT, PROFIT, YOU, WIN
earns double its point count. Spelling certain 10-letter Winning Words:
 REPUBLICAN, PATRIOTISM, CAPITALISM, PRODUCTION
earns 150 points and wins the game outright.

Description from box back translated from Polish:

Meet eye to eye with dangerous dinosaurs!!! Learn and master the habits each of them and trail the most dangerous - Tyrannosaurus. When you finish pursuit of the lord of prehistoric animals - try your force, playing cards with the most interesting and dangerous reptiles.

Box Content:
game board, 32 cards with dinosaurs, Tyrannosaurus card, 8 big mat to colour, 4 pawns, dice, rules

In the grand tradition of miniature sports games such as Blood Bowl, comes Nuthin But Net! a board game of three-on-three basketball for fantasy races which range from standard humans, to elves, ratmen, and lizard folk.

Each player has a team of five, each with unique stats for skills such as ball handling, shooting and dunking, Three players are on the half-court at a time, and the action is fast and furious as you play to a win, usually 21 points.

Now produced by Impact! Miniatures www.impactminiatures.com

Five large wooden dinosaurs are moving towards trees and picking up one tree from each corner of the game board. All dinosaurs which get back to their starting square before the (neutral) T-Rex gets there is a winner. Dinosaurs are moved by a color die which determines the color of the next square they can move to.

item.description:
Ubongo Extreme: Fun-Size Edition is an "extreme" version of the Ubongo travel game or a portable version of Ubongo Extrem — one of those.

In the game, players race to solve spatial puzzles by filling spaces with Tetris-like pieces that are composed of connected hexagons instead of squares. The game comes with two difficulty levels so that beginners can compete with more experienced players, with one side of the card having a puzzle that requires three pieces to solve it and the other side having a puzzle that requires four pieces.

item.description:
Mythology is a subject of never-ending fascination! Myths of creation, of floods, of heroes - these and many others crop up in the myths of numerous cultures throughout the world. Mythology has inspired painters, sculptors, writers and other artists over the centuries.

Now, world mythology is encompassed, as is reasonably possible, within Mythomachy, the top educational, brain development and family-friendly entertaining brand designed to teach children about mythology as well as to help them discover new ways to foster their intelligence. Mythomachy intends to be represented across all major categories of youth products with focus on toys, publishing and other consumer product categories, including apparel, accessories, back-to-school and more as this exciting property has enormous branding and licensing potential for the boy and girl audience.

There is a lot of excitement behind Mythomachy Trading Card Game distributed first across retail venues nationwide in Greece. Unlike most trading card games, which are based on fantasy, Mythomachy is solidly anchored in the global universe of authentic myths and legends.

Mythomachy TCG first edition includes a 350-card set available in 6-card booster packs, providing a tremendous base of consumer-tested artwork and game play, taking into account the age-sensitive profile of its target, kids Ages 7 and up.

In an already male-saturated market, Mythomachy is enjoyed as much by female fans as male because of its directly educational quality profile and learning benefits.

"The game you can play while you watch your 'Pocahontas' video!"

(c)1996

Players move around a colorful board as they watch the movie. When certain events occur during the film players take Canoe Cards or Grandmother Willow cards from the deck. These cards are used to help the players get to the finish line and win the game.

Includes board, spinner, cards, tokens, and a package of Nestle Quik!

A compendium of 4 games to accompany the Horrible Science collection of books. Contains:

- Spiders and twigs game: A straight roll and move with plastic bugs for counters.

- Spitting Cobra: Use the water pistol to try to hit the squishy eyeball.

- Archer Fish: Use the water pistol to try to hit the plastic bugs.

- Queen Bee!: A hex based draughts/checkers variant.

Echelon is a three-dimensional abstract strategy game in which two players build a structure while attempting to get five cubes of their own color in a row.

Starting with a black "starting cube", players alternate placing in one of two ways:

1) Playing three cubes in a row (as viewed from above), with at least one cube on top of a preexisting one, or;

2) Playing two cubes as above, but also removing an edge-adjacent cube from the structure.

The game also includes two "anchor cubes" of each color, which may not be removed from play by either player, as well as one "shift cube" for each, which may only be removed by the owning player.

Note: the front of the package claims the game is suitable for 2-4 players, but the interior of the rulebook reveals that doing so entails purchasing another set of cubes (they were apparently sold in two sets; one with red and blue cubes, and the other with green and purple).

name.value: La dulce casita de la bruja Pirula

item.description: Nibble, nibble, little mouse, take some sweeties off my house. Whoever can collect the most cookies will win this bewitched game of skill for 2-4 players. But be careful: the roof may collapse and wake up the witch!

Published by and using 28mm miniatures by Eureka Miniatures in Australia, this abstract boardgame is set in their Pax Limpopo universe. The British lancers can only move diagonally forward. The clockwork Russian pigs can only move orthogonally like a rook (again, never backward). The abandoned, unhappy horses are terrain pieces but can be moved like a pawn (but into any of the eight squares around it) if the dice are right. Movement is blocked by the horses, your opponent's pieces and your own pieces. However, if you can end a move on an opponent's piece, it is removed from the game. The first player to get three of his pieces to his opponent's start line (or prevents his opponent from winning) wins the game.

Each turn, two six-sided dice are rolled and the results, like in backgammon, can move one or two of your pieces. On a result of doubles, a player can move one horse and then take his regular move, or on any result of one, can move a horse instead of moving one of his pieces.

The game comes with a full colour 11" x 17" board (not mounted), 6 British Lancers on unicycles, 6 Russian clockwork pigs, and 6 forlorn-looking horses sitting on their rumps. All figures come unpainted. The pigs must be assembled. There is a one-page instruction sheet with a "history" of the battle on the back.

The sassy pony named Lucky has again startled the horses at the “Happy Horses” farm. The horses take to their heels.
Who with a bit of luck and thought will be able to find most of their horses?

A memory game for 2-4 players.

Which is the best herding dog in the valley of the hungry wolves? Shouting “Woof!” and “Baa” the players move round the meadow. It’s now or never to catch up with the next dog and be the first to collect three sheep and win this romping die game for 2-4 players.

Hungry Wolves (Würfelwölfe) is a hectic action game with dice. The players circle a flock of sheep with their herding dogs. All players throw their dice simultaneously and have to perform an action as fast as possible depending on the dice throw, e.g. saying "Woof!" or running around the table. 
Also, the movement of the dog depends on the dice throw.

As soon as the action is performed, the dice throwing continues. When one dog reaches or overtakes another, the round ends and the faster dog gets a sheep from the flock as a reward.

The game is on the recommendation list of the SdJ-jury 2009.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Haba's classic Orchard for the smallest ones. The rules are adjusted to their age and the game material is especially designed for a small childs' hand. The beautiful and handy wooden pieces are also very suitable for free play and fostering better motor skills.

A co-operative game for 1 - 4 players, Ages 2 and up

link.value: HABA My Very First Games series

item.description:
The children walk with dwarf Colorful through the vivid Colorland. They visit the red dwarf, the green one ...Who will be the first to collect the presents?

A fantastic educational game collection for 2-4 players about recognizing and classifying colors.

Includes co-operative variation which also can be played solo.
